title: Mauricio Pochettino hits back at rumours he’s lost Spurs dressing room
text:
Mauricio Pochettino has reacted angrily to rumours about the Tottenham squad (Picture: Getty)

Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino hit back at claims he’s lost the dressing room after his side’s 5-0 win against Red Star Belgrade.

Spurs have made a dismal start to the season and reports last week claimed the squad blamed their poor form on Pochettino’s training methods.

The Argentine often demands his players spend the night at the club’s training ground after European matches, which drastically impacts their free time. It’s also claimed that the squad are unhappy with a lack of days off and they feel mentally burdened by the demands put on them by Pochettino.

The players didn’t appear to be carrying much mental baggage during their demolishing of Belgrade, who were put to the sword by braces from Harry Kane and Heung-Min Son, as well as a goal from Erik Lamela.

Spurs refound their form against Red Star (Picture: Getty)

And, speaking after the game, Pochettino raised the rumours himself in an interview with BT Sport and dismissed the suggestion as nonsense.

Asked if the result was a positive one for his side, Pochettino said: ‘Yes for the confidence and then tomorrow day off because we score five goals…there’s always rumours and complaints about a day off [laughs].

‘I say “okay, you want day off? Then day off tomorrow. If you’re going to be happy like this with a day off then fine, day off”.

‘Always in football you try to find reasons from nowhere but the problem was on the pitch. Our performances weren’t great and that’s all.’

Pochettino reverted to a 4-2-3-1, pairing Tanguy Ndombele with Moussa Sissoko behind a front four of Kane, Son, Dele Alli and Lamela.

Spurs raced into a 2-0 lead thanks to their high energy pressing game and it appeared to be a return to the tactics that made Pochettino such a success in north London.

The Argentine admits the club have lost their way since last season but says it’s how you respond to setbacks that matter.

‘You always try to find a way….a spark for the team to start again,’ said Pochettino.

‘There are things in football you cannot explain. The dynamic changed after the final of the Champions League of course it’s so difficult and complex to explain but the most important thing is to build together, not to create drama, to stay calm and to believe. To know this can happen in any team but to stay strong in your principles and translate that confidence to the squad.

‘Of course you cannot stop the rumours but the most important thing is to show we are together. If we don’t win then the reason is because we are not performing, not some stupid thing happen inside.’
